titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gilbert A. Harrison Papers Relating to Thornton Wilder
Gilbert A. Harrison Papers Relating to Thornton Wilder
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 05:09

did.unittitle: Gilbert A. Harrison papers relating to Thornton Wilder

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection contains research files, interviews, correspondence, writings, and other materials relating to Gilbert A. Harrison's biography of Thornton Wilder, The Enthusiast: A Life of Thornton Wilder (New Haven: Ticknor & Fields, 1983). Harrison's research files, which include notes, photocopies of correspondence and writings, and clippings, make up the bulk of the collection. In addition to the research files, the collection includes: sound recordings of interviews with members of the Wilder family and others, such as Alfred Hitchcock and Lillian Gish; correspondence with Wilder family, scholars, and publishers; a corrected draft of the biography and reviews; and other materials, including biographical information, a copy of Wilder's will, and reference photographs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Gilbert A. Harrison, 1984 and 1985.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 15-16 (sound recordings): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Gilbert A. Harrison Papers Relating to Thornton Wilder is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gilbert A. Harrison Papers Relating to Thornton Wilder. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit. This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
Formerly classed as Uncat ZA MS 324 and Uncat ZA MS 352.

bioghist.head: Gilbert A. Harrison (1915-2008)
bioghist.p: Gilbert A. Harrison was born in Detroit on May 18, 1915, one of three children to Samuel and Mabel Wolfe Harrison. He earned a B.A. degree in psychology from UCLA in 1937 and went on to serve in the U.S. Army in World War II. Following the war, in 1948, Harrison became national chairman of the American Veterans Committe. In 1953, with his wife, Anne Blaine, he purchased The New Republic , where he served as publisher and editor until 1974. Harrison was the author of two books, A Timeless Affair: The Life of Anita McCormick Blaine (1979), a biography of his grandmother-in-law, and The Enthusiast: A Life of Thornton Wilder (1983), and editor of several others, including Gertrude Stein's America (1965) and The Critic as Artist (1972).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains research files, interviews, correspondence, writings, and other materials relating to Gilbert A. Harrison's biography of Thornton Wilder, The Enthusiast: A Life of Thornton Wilder (1983). Harrison's research files, which include notes, photocopies of correspondence and writings, and clippings, make up the bulk of the collection. In addition to the research files, there are audio recordings of interviews with members of the Wilder family and others, such as Alfred Hitchcock and Lillian Gish, correspondence with Wilder family, scholars, and publishers, a corrected draft of the biography, and reviews. Other materials include biographical information, a copy of Wilder's will, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Research Files, 1976-[1983]. II. Interviews, 1979-1981. III. Correspondence, 1956-1985. IV. Writings, 1980-1984. V. Other Papers, 1984.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically and alphabetically by Harrison's folder headings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Gilbert A. Harrison papers consist of research files for Harrison's biography of Thornton Wilder, The Enthusiast: A Life of Thornton Wilder (1983). In addition to Harrison's notes, the research files contain a significant quantity of photocopies of correspondence and writings relating to Wilder, and clippings. Though largely undated, the files most likely date from the earliest interviews and correspondence in 1979 to publication of the biography in 1983.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by audio cassette label heading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Interviews, contains sound recordings of interviews conducted by Harrison with members of the Wilder family and others. Interviewees include Amos Wilder, Isabel Wilder, Janet Wilder Dakin, "Tappy" Wilder, Alfred Hitchcock, Lillian Gish, Malcolm Cowley, and Catherine Coffin.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Correspondence, contains letters relating to Harrison's research project on Wilder. Letters between Harrison and others date chiefly from the research project, from 1979 through 1983, with a few exceptions, including copies of third-party correspondence (enclosures).
Additional correspondence relating to publication and reception of Harrison's biography can be found in Series IV. Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes copies of third-party correspondence between Isabel Wilder and others dating from 1961 to 1981

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains copies of third-party correspondence dating from 1935 to 1975

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in order of the creative process.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Writings, consists of correspondence, a corrected draft, and reviews relating to Harrison's biography of Thornton Wilder, The Enthusiast: A Life of Thornton Wilder . The correspondence contains letters with his literary agent, Brandt & Brandt, and publisher, Ticknor & Fields, documenting production of the book, and fan mail. The fan mail and reviews document critical reception of the book.

unittitle.title: The Enthusiast: A Life of Thornton Wilder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V, Other Papers, contains biographical information on Thornton and other Wilder family members, a copy of Wilder's 1967 will and testament, and photographs. Photographs include individual portraits and snapshots of Wilder and several images of Wilder with political and cultural figures, including Eleanor Lansing Dulles, Willi Brandt, and Ethel Waters, at the opening of Congress Hall in Berlin in 1957.
